context.description: Select the default Web server to be used for Web service creation.
Select the default server run-time environment to be used for Web service creation.
Select the default J2EE version to be used for Web service creation.
Use this wizard to add and remove handlers for a Web service. The order in which they are listed represents the order in which the handlers will be acted upon.
Enter the required information to generate a standardized WSDL reference (WSIL) document in your project.
Enter the name of the WSIL document being generated, or accept the default.
Browse to the location of a WSDL or WSIL file from which the new WSIL document will be generated.
This lists all the WSDL URIs that will be included in the WSIL document.
Use this page to select the Java bean or class used to create the Web service.

Enter the name of the Java bean to be used to create the Web service. Defaults the selected Java bean. Click Browse classes to view the bean class of the selected Java bean. The bean class is a model or template (an abstract data type) that can be instantiated to create objects with a common definition and therefore, common properties, operations, and behavior. Click Browse files to select a Java bean from the project.
Click to view the bean class of the selected Java bean.
Browse to the correct Java bean to be used to create the Web service.
Select the type of Web service you want to generate and any file and folder options for your Web service.
Allows you to overwrite files without receiving a warning message asking for confirmation when overwriting files.
Select to create folders and folder structures without receiving a warning message asking for confirmation.
The generated Java bean proxy provides a remote procedure call interface to the Web service.
Select this check box to test the generated proxy.
Click to start the server. If you leave the box unchecked you will have to manually start the server.
Select the type of Web service you want to build. Your selection will affect the files available for selection.
Select the type of Web service you want to build. Your selection will affect the files available for selection.
Select this check box to launch the Web service in the Web Services Explorer in order to examine it.
Select this checkbox to launch the Web Services Explorer in order to publish the Web service to a UDDI registry.
The generated Java bean proxy provides a remote procedure call interface to the Web service.
Select the client proxy type. The generated Java bean proxy provides a remote procedure call interface to the Web service.
Select to check out files without receiving a warning message asking for confirmation.
Select from the listed EAR projects.
Select from the listed Java beans.
Use this page to select the Java bean or class used to create the Web service.

Enter the name of the Java bean to be used to create the Web service. Defaults the selected Java bean. Click Browse classes to view the bean class of the selected Java bean. The bean class is a model or template (an abstract data type) that can be instantiated to create objects with a common definition and therefore, common properties, operations, and behavior. Click Browse files to select a Java bean from the project.
Click to view the bean class of the selected Java bean.
Browse to the correct Java bean to be used to create the Web service.
Use this page to select the WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document that will be used to create the Web service.
Enter the path to a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.
Browse to the location of a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.
Select this check box to generate a standardized WSDL reference (WSIL) document in your project.
Enter the path to an existing WSIL document, or select the location where the WSIL document will be created.
Browse to the location of an existing WSIL document
Select to launch the Web Services Explorer to allow you to publish the Web service.
If selected will launch the Web Services Explorer to allow you to publish the Web service.
Select the scenario configuration for run-time environments, servers, and projects.
This is the server-side run-time environment which the Web service will use. To change this click Edit.
This is the server-side server on which the Web service will run. To change this click Edit.

Select the Web project or EJB project in which the Web service will be created. The wizard will create the Web project for you if it does not already exist. If you are using an EJB project, it must already exist.
Select the EJB project in which the Web service will be created.
This is the client-side run-time environment which the Web service will use. To change this click Edit.
This is the client-side server on which the Web service will run. To change this click Edit.
Select the project in which the Web service client will be created. The wizard will generate this project if it does not already exist.
Select from the listed project types the type of project that you want created to contain your Web service client.

Select from the listed EAR projects. It is recommended that you select different EARs for the client and the service to avoid runtime errors. The wizard will create the EAR for you if it does not already exist.
The sample Web application demonstrates how to code the proxy file.
If selected will launch the sample Web application in the Web browser.
The sample Web application demonstrates how to code the proxy file.

The methods that can be invoked on the service object and encoding styles for the method inputs and outputs. Only selected methods will be available for invocation and documented in the WSDL. Select encoding styles for input parameters and output return. The methods list will display supported methods for a selected service object.
Click this button to add all the available methods to the Web service sample proxy.
Click this button to remove all the available methods to the Web service sample proxy.
Folder into which your Web service JSPs are deposited.
Click to find the folder into which your Web service JSPs are deposited.
Select an existing project into which your sample will be generated.

Folder into which the fully qualified proxy is generated. Defaults to the source folder inside of your Web project.Folder into which the fully qualified proxy is generated. Defaults to the source folder inside of your Web project.
Select this check box to run the sample application on the server.
Select the EAR in which you want your Web service sample application created.
Use this page to select the WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document that will be used to create the Web service.
Enter the path to a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.
Browse to the location of a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.
Enter the user name used for HTTP basic authentication.
Enter the password used for HTTP basic authentication.
